chapter: Class XII - Chapter 2: Electrostatic Potential and Capacitance
question_plain: Two charges 5 × 10^{-8} C and -3 × 10^{-8} C are located 16 cm apart. At what point(s) on the line joining the two charges is the electric potential zero? Take the potential at infinity to be zero.
question_latex: Two charges $5 \times 10^{-8}$ C and $-3 \times 10^{-8}$ C are located 16 cm apart. At what point(s) on the line joining the two charges is the electric potential zero? Take the potential at infinity to be zero.
correct_answer_plain: Two points: (i) 10 cm from the positive charge (between the charges), (ii) 40 cm from the positive charge (outside, beyond the negative charge)
correct_answer_latex: Two points: (i) 10 cm from $q_1$ (between the charges), (ii) 40 cm from $q_1$ (outside, beyond $q_2$)
hint: Set V = 0 at point P. Use V = kq/r for each charge and solve for position where potentials cancel.
solution_steps_latex: Let positive charge $q_1 = 5 \times 10^{-8}$ C at point A, negative $q_2 = -3 \times 10^{-8}$ C at B. Distance AB = 16 cm = 0.16 m.
**Point 1 — Between the charges:** Let P be at distance $x$ from A (so distance from B = $0.16 - x$).
**Point 2 — Outside, beyond $q_2$:** Let P be at distance $x$ from B (so from A = $0.16 + x$).
So this point is 24 cm from $q_2$, i.e. **40 cm from $q_1$** (outside the segment).
Both points satisfy $V = 0$. There is no zero-potential point on the other side (beyond $q_1$) since both contributions would be positive there.

visual_content.diagram_description: Two point charges on a horizontal line: positive charge q₁ = +5×10⁻⁸ C on the left and negative charge q₂ = −3×10⁻⁸ C on the right, separated by 16 cm. Two zero-potential points are marked — one between the charges (10 cm from q₁) and one outside the segment beyond q₂ (40 cm from q₁).

chapter: Class XII - Chapter 2: Electrostatic Potential and Capacitance
question_plain: Two charges 2 µC and -2 µC are placed at points A and B 6 cm apart. (a) Identify an equipotential surface of the system. (b) What is the direction of the electric field at every point on this surface?
question_latex: Two charges $2 \ \mu$C and $-2 \ \mu$C are placed at points A and B 6 cm apart. (a) Identify an equipotential surface of the system. (b) What is the direction of the electric field at every point on this surface?
correct_answer_plain: (a) The plane perpendicular to AB and passing through the midpoint (perpendicular bisector plane). (b) The electric field is perpendicular to the equipotential surface (along AB direction).
correct_answer_latex: (a) Plane perpendicular to line AB passing through midpoint. (b) Electric field is normal to the surface (parallel to AB).
hint: For equal and opposite charges, midpoint has V = 0. Equipotential surfaces are perpendicular to field lines.
solution_steps_latex: Charges are equal in magnitude, opposite in sign → system resembles dipole.
At midpoint of AB, potential due to both charges cancel → V = 0.
All points equidistant from +q and -q have same potential (V = 0).
This locus is the plane perpendicular to AB passing through midpoint → equipotential surface is the perpendicular bisector plane.
Electric field lines are always perpendicular to equipotential surfaces.
On this plane, E is normal to the plane → direction along AB (from + to - charge).

visual_content.diagram_description: Two charges +2 μC at A and -2 μC at B, 6 cm apart. Plane perpendicular to AB at midpoint is the V = 0 equipotential surface.

to_find: (b) Direction of E on that surface

chapter: Class XII - Chapter 2: Electrostatic Potential and Capacitance
question_plain: Explain what would happen if in the capacitor given in Exercise 2.8, a 3 mm thick mica sheet (of dielectric constant = 6) were inserted between the plates (a) while the voltage supply remained connected. (b) after the supply was disconnected.
question_latex: Explain what would happen if in the capacitor given in Exercise 2.8, a 3 mm thick mica sheet (of dielectric constant = 6) were inserted between the plates (a) while the voltage supply remained connected. (b) after the supply was disconnected.
correct_answer_plain: (a) C' = 108 pF, Q' = 1.08 × 10^{-8} C, V = 100 V (unchanged), energy increases 6×. (b) C' = 108 pF, Q = 1.8 nC (unchanged), V' ≈ 16.6 V, energy decreases to 1/6.
hint: When dielectric is inserted: (connected) V constant → Q and U increase by K. (disconnected) Q constant → V and U decrease by K.
solution_steps_latex: Mica dielectric: $K = 6$, thickness = 3 mm = plate separation → completely fills the gap.
**(a) Battery stays connected** → $V = 100$ V held constant.
$U' = \frac{1}{2}C'V^2 = 6U_0$ (energy increases 6×; extra energy supplied by battery)
**(b) Battery disconnected first** → charge $Q_0 = 1.8$ nC is conserved.

visual_content.diagram_description: The parallel plate capacitor from Ex 2.8 (A = 6×10⁻³ m², d = 3 mm) with a 3 mm thick mica sheet (κ = 6) inserted between the plates, completely filling the gap. Two scenarios illustrated: (a) battery remains connected — voltage stays at 100 V, charge increases; (b) battery disconnected before insertion — charge stays the same, voltage drops.

given: Mica sheet thickness = 3 mm (fills entire gap)

hint: Initial energy = ½ C V². After connection (parallel), total C becomes 2C, charge conserved → new V = V/2 → final energy = ¼ initial.
solution_steps_latex: Charge on first capacitor $Q = C V = 6 \times 10^{-10} \times 200 = 1.2 \times 10^{-7}$ C
Disconnected and connected to identical uncharged capacitor → parallel combination

visual_content.diagram_description: Two-stage circuit: Stage 1 — a 600 pF capacitor C₁ is charged to 200 V by a battery, then the battery is disconnected. Stage 2 — the charged C₁ is connected in parallel to an identical uncharged 600 pF capacitor C₂. Charge redistributes equally, each capacitor settles at 100 V, and half the original energy is lost as heat.

formulas_used: Charge conservation in parallel: $Q = C_1 V_1 = (C_1 + C_2) V'$
